Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for International Symposium on Semiconductor Light Emitting Devices. To be Held in Banff, Canada, October 8-12, 2017

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is an NSF support for increasing the diversity of speakers and enhancing student participation at the 11th International Symposium on Semiconductor Light Emitting Devices (ISSLED). The ISSLED is a specialized biannual international meeting covering current challenges in semiconductor light emitting devices. This year meeting will be in Banff (Canada). The ISSLED and the LED research community as a whole stands to benefit from an increase in the invited speakers and attendees at the symposium that are underrepresented minorities.
The ISSLED Symposium is a specialized biannual international meeting covering current challenges in semiconductor light emitting devices. The participants are researchers from academia, national institutes, and industry and travel from all parts of the world. To continue this trend, speakers are invited from various research fields and ethnic/cultural backgrounds in an effort to improve the diversity of symposium attendees. A great deal of attention is given to involve students and young researcher who are just beginning their research careers.
The funds will enable the organizers to offer travel support for invited speakers who are underrepresented minorities in the LED device research community. The technical program will provide student participants the opportunity to gain exposure to new materials and devices, their basic physics, and their engineering applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is related to the travel support for young professionals to attend the 11th International Symposium on Semiconductor Light Emitting Devices (ISSLED), which was held in Banff, Canada, Oct. 8-12, 2017. The conference was chaired by Prof. Zetian Mi at University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Dr. George Wang at Sandia National Labs, and Prof. Zlatko Sitar at North Carolina State University. The participant support was in the form of small grants to help covering registration cost and travel of selected individuals, including students, post-docs, and young researchers. The priority was given to qualified students from the underrepresented groups and young researchers at the beginning of their career.

ISSLED is a specialized biannual international meeting covering current challenges in semiconductor light emitting devices. By addressing various challenges in greater depth and detail not possible in broader topical and society meetings, the symposium aims at educating young researchers by offering broader plenary talks and focused discussions. The participants were researchers from the academia, national institutes, and industry and came from all parts of the world and a great deal of attention was given to involve students and young researcher who were just beginning their research careers. The goal of the symposium was to share and exchange the latest discoveries on light emitting phenomena in semiconductors among various researchers, as well as to critically address major roadblocks related to device performance, and to discuss future trends. The latter was particularly important and useful for early-career researchers.

One of the big topics in ISSLED 2017 was related to challenges in UV light emitters, which is an up and coming field that faces a lot of scientific challenges and requires a new look at epitaxy, doping, point defects, and contacts. This symposium was instrumental to set a foundation for new predictive models that would adequately describe the existing experimental results and observed phenomena, and to provide guidance for future quantitative research.

The symposium organizers and committee members were truly committed to impart knowledge and to foster a new generation of scientist and critical thinkers in the field. A large fraction of participants (more than 50%) were students or young researchers at the beginning of their careers. This was achieved in two ways: (1) by directly targeting and inviting young underrepresented researchers in the field, and (2) by encouraging the leaders of established groups to enable student participation. In many cases, offering discounted registration fees or a small travel grant made a difference between a student being able to attend or not.

To accomplish it’s objectives, the meeting was truly interdisciplinary and brought together scientists from physics, materials science, electrical engineering, and mechanical engineering to address materials synthesis and process design, materials growth and property control, optical properties and quantum phenomena, and electrical and thermal transport. Since each of these topics is in some way related to others, they require a global understanding of interdependence and cannot be discussed or treated in isolation. This approach offered young researcher a new, broader view of interconnected science and new tools for addressing complex and multifaceted scientific problems.
